channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Nvidia’s Quarterly Profit Hits $43 Billion on Strong A.I. Chip Sales
item.description: Total profit for the fiscal year was $120 billion, the company said. Three years ago, it was just $4.4 billion.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nvidia, led by Jensen Huang, above, said quarterly revenue from its chips for A.I. data centers had risen 71 percent to $61.7 billion.

item.title: Can A.I. Detection Tools Really Spot Fake Images and Videos?
item.description: Artificial intelligence detectors are increasingly used to check the veracity of content online. We ran more than 1,000 tests and found several strengths and plenty of weaknesses.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson

item.title: Pentagon Gives Anthropic an Ultimatum Over the Company’s A.I. Model
item.description: Anthropic insists on limits on how its technology is used and could be labeled a supply chain risk if it fails to accept the military’s demands.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth summoned the chief executive of Anthropic to Washington for a meeting on Tuesday.

item.title: The Looming Taiwan Chip Disaster That Silicon Valley Has Long Ignored
item.description: If China invades Taiwan and cuts off its chip exports to American companies, the tech industry and the U.S. economy would be crippled.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Ben Jones; Source Photographs by Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times; Loren Elliott for The New York Times; Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: A.I. Dating Apps Complicate China’s Efforts to Boost Birthrate
item.description: As China grapples with a shrinking population and historically low birthrate, people are finding romance with chatbots instead.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Murphy Zhao and Meaghan Tobin
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Lawmakers Ask Tech Companies What User Data They Provided to D.H.S.
item.description: The requests followed Times reporting that the Department of Homeland Security had sent Meta and other companies subpoenas for information on accounts that track or comment on ICE.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Bennie Thompson of Mississippi is one of three Democratic lawmakers asking tech companies about requests for user data from the Department of Homeland Security.

item.title: Podcasts? TV Talk Shows? Netflix Just Hopes They’re Hits.
item.description: The podcasts in the streamer’s debut crop, including “The Pete Davidson Show,” have revived metaphysical questions about the definition of the medium.
item.dc:creator: Reggie Ugwu
item.category: The White House With Michael Irvin (TV Program)

item.title: Wayve, an A.I. Driverless Car Start-Up in Europe, Raises $1.2 Billion
item.description: The London-based company is building a system that uses artificial intelligence to power autonomous vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: The Asahi Shimbun, via Getty Images
item.media:description: New funding values Wayve at $8.6 billion.

item.title: Senator Blumenthal Opens Inquiry Into Iran Transactions on Binance
item.description: Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut sent a letter to Binance asking about the flow of $1.7 billion from accounts on the crypto exchange to Iranian entities.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Michael Forsythe
item.category: Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross for The New York Times
item.media:description: In a letter to Binance, Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut asked for records about the company’s dealings with two Hong Kong entities identified by the exchange’s investigators as the origin of the transfers to Iran.

item.title: How Jeffrey Epstein Ingratiated Himself With Top Microsoft Executives
item.description: For more than two decades, the convicted sex offender developed a network at the tech giant, making him privy to succession discussions and other business.
item.dc:creator: Erin Griffith and Karen Weise

item.title: More Than Half of Teens Use Chatbots for Schoolwork, Survey Finds
item.description: A new study from the Pew Research Center finds teenagers think chatbot-assisted cheating has become “a regular feature of student life.”
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:credit: Ysa Pérez for The New York Times

item.title: Intel Strikes Deal With a Chip Start-Up Its C.E.O. Invested In
item.description: A technical partnership embraces SambaNova Systems, which Intel’s chief, Lip-Bu Tan, helps lead as an investor and chairman.
item.dc:creator: Don Clark
item.media:credit: Laure Andrillon/Reuters
item.media:description: Intel said Lip-Bu Tan, its chief executive, had recused himself from talks involving SambaNova Systems.

item.title: Anthropic Accuses 3 Chinese Companies of Harvesting Its Data
item.description: The San Francisco start-up claimed that DeepSeek, Moonshot and MiniMax used approximately 24,000 fraudulent accounts to train their own chatbots.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.category: Beijing Moonshot AI Technology Co Ltd
item.media:credit: Cfoto/Future Publishing, via Getty Images
item.media:description: DeepSeek is among the three Chinese start-ups accused of using data from Anthropic’s A.I. system to train their own, a process called distillation.

item.title: Pentagon Summons Anthropic Chief in Dispute Over A.I. Limits
item.description: The artificial intelligence company has demanded that some guardrails be put in place as it negotiates a contract with the Defense Department.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dario Amodei, the chief executive of Anthropic, will meet with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth at the Pentagon.

item.title: Jeff and Lauren Sánchez Bezos Will Be Honorary Chairs of the Met Gala
item.description: The news came tucked into the second page of a recent news release.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeff Bezos and Lauren Sánchez Bezos at a Kering Foundation gala in New York in September.

item.title: Binance Employees Find $1.7 Billion in Crypto Was Sent to Iranian Entities
item.description: Binance pledged to crack down on crime. But internal investigators at the world’s largest crypto exchange continued to find evidence of potential legal violations on the platform.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Michael Forsythe
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Binance, the world’s largest venue for crypto trading, has continued to find evidence of potential legal violations on its platform, even after it pleaded guilty to breaking anti-money-laundering laws in 2023.

item.title: Backed by Anthropic, a Super PAC Group Begins an Ad Blitz in Support of A.I. Regulation
item.description: The ads by Public First Action, which started airing on Monday, are part of an escalating political war over artificial intelligence before the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anthropic’s chief executive, Dario Amodei, has pushed for regulations to create guardrails on artificial intelligence.

item.title: Need an Outfit? Pickle Clothing Rental App Helps Users Stay on Trend.
item.description: Pickle, a new peer-to-peer apparel-rental app, helps users stay on trend without having to go into debt or rely on climate-unfriendly fast fashion.
item.dc:creator: Kasia Pilat

item.title: ‘A.I. Literacy’ Is the New Drivers’ Ed at This Newark School
item.description: Teachers say they want to equip high school students to drive artificial intelligence, rather than be mere passengers steered by chatbots.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:credit: Juan Arredondo for The New York Times
item.media:description: In February, North Star Academy Washington Park High School started a new A.I. class for seniors.

item.title: People Loved the Dot-Com Boom. The A.I. Boom, Not So Much.
item.description: Tech leaders are beginning to worry about the public’s underwhelming enthusiasm for their plans to remake the world with artificial intelligence. Will that burst the bubble?
item.dc:creator: David Streitfeld
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Sam Altman, the chief executive of OpenAI, recently said artificial intelligence was spreading more slowly than he had expected.

item.title: The Pentagon vs. Anthropic + An A.I. Agent Slandered Me + Hot Mess Express
item.description: This would be an unprecedented escalation against a U.S. company.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Rachel Cohn, Whitney Jones, Vjeran Pavic, Katie McMurran, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Rowan Niemisto
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Photo: Joshua Roberts/Reuters

item.title: His Team Devised Ways to Keep World Cup Crowds Safe
item.description: Michael Silevitch leads a research center dedicated to protecting busy public spaces. Last April, he was instructed to “end all work” immediately.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller
item.media:credit: Simon Simard for The New York Times

item.title: A.I. Isn’t Coming for Every White-Collar Job. At Least Not Yet.
item.description: Tech workers are increasingly worried that the artificial intelligence they are building will replace them. But some are optimistic that it is just one more tool to work with.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Adam Glanzman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Though powerful, code generators still require extensive oversight, according to researchers and programmers.

item.title: West Virginia Sues Apple, Claiming It Allows Sharing of Child Sexual Abuse Material
item.description: The state’s attorney general said in a lawsuit filed on Thursday that the company declined to use tools that recognize the material stored on iCloud.
item.dc:creator: Kalley Huang
item.media:credit: Mike Segar/Reuters
